trans-unit.source: Getting started with Azure Queue storage and Visual Studio connected services (Cloud Service projects)
trans-unit.target: Getting started with Azure Queue storage and Visual Studio connected services (Cloud Service projects)

trans-unit.source: How to get started using Azure Queue storage in a cloud service project in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: How to get started using Azure Queue storage in a cloud service project in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to get started using Azure Queue storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in a cloud services project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to get started using Azure Queue storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in a cloud services project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.

trans-unit.source: We'll show you how to create a queue in code.
trans-unit.target: We'll show you how to create a queue in code.

trans-unit.source: We'll also show you how to perform basic queue operations, such as adding, modifying, reading and removing queue messages.
trans-unit.target: We'll also show you how to perform basic queue operations, such as adding, modifying, reading and removing queue messages.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C# code and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C# code and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Add Connected Services operation installs the appropriate NuGet packages to access Azure storage in your project and adds the connection string for the storage account to your project configuration files.
trans-unit.target: The Add Connected Services operation installs the appropriate NuGet packages to access Azure storage in your project and adds the connection string for the storage account to your project configuration files.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to use Queue Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information on manipulating queues in code.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to use Queue Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information on manipulating queues in code.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Storage documentation</linkText><title></title> for general information about Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Storage documentation</linkText><title></title> for general information about Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Cloud Services documentation</linkText><title></title> for general information about Azure cloud services.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Cloud Services documentation</linkText><title></title> for general information about Azure cloud services.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>ASP.NET</linkText><title></title> for more information about programming ASP.NET applications.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>ASP.NET</linkText><title></title> for more information about programming ASP.NET applications.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queue storage is a service for storing large numbers of messages that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via authenticated calls using HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queue storage is a service for storing large numbers of messages that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via authenticated calls using HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: A single queue message can be up to 64 KB in size, and a queue can contain millions of messages, up to the total capacity limit of a storage account.
trans-unit.target: A single queue message can be up to 64 KB in size, and a queue can contain millions of messages, up to the total capacity limit of a storage account.

trans-unit.source: To access queues in Visual Studio Cloud Services projects, you need to include the following items to any C# source file that access Azure Queue storage.
trans-unit.target: To access queues in Visual Studio Cloud Services projects, you need to include the following items to any C# source file that access Azure Queue storage.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the namespace declarations at the top of the C# file include these using statements.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the namespace declarations at the top of the C# file include these using statements.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudQueueClient object to reference the queue objects in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudQueueClient object to reference the queue objects in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudQueue object to reference a specific queue.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudQueue object to reference a specific queue.

trans-unit.source: NOTE: Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following samples.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following samples.

trans-unit.source: To create the queue in code, just add a call to CreateIfNotExists.
trans-unit.target: To create the queue in code, just add a call to CreateIfNotExists.

trans-unit.source: To insert a message into an existing queue, create a new CloudQueueMessage object, then call the AddMessage method.
trans-unit.target: To insert a message into an existing queue, create a new CloudQueueMessage object, then call the AddMessage method.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueMessage object can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueMessage object can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example which inserts the message 'Hello, World'.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example which inserts the message 'Hello, World'.

trans-unit.source: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the PeekMessage method.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the PeekMessage method.

trans-unit.source: Your code can remove (de-queue) a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code can remove (de-queue) a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: Call GetMessage to get the next message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: Call GetMessage to get the next message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.
trans-unit.target: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.

trans-unit.source: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: By default, this message stays invisible for 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: To finish removing the message from the queue, call DeleteMessage.
trans-unit.target: To finish removing the message from the queue, call DeleteMessage.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: The following code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: The following code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue.

trans-unit.source: You can get a batch of messages (up to 32).
trans-unit.target: You can get a batch of messages (up to 32).

trans-unit.source: You can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.
trans-unit.target: You can set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses the GetMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses the GetMessages method to get 20 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message using a foreach loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message using a foreach loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.

trans-unit.source: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to GetMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.
trans-unit.target: Note that the 5 minutes starts for all messages at the same time, so after 5 minutes have passed since the call to GetMessages, any messages which have not been deleted will become visible again.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example:

trans-unit.source: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.
trans-unit.target: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The FetchAttributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.
trans-unit.target: The FetchAttributes method asks the Queue service to retrieve the queue attributes, including the message count.

trans-unit.source: The ApproximateMethodCount property returns the last value retrieved by the FetchAttributes method, without calling the Queue service.
trans-unit.target: The ApproximateMethodCount property returns the last value retrieved by the FetchAttributes method, without calling the Queue service.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to use the Async-Await pattern with common Azure Queue APIs.
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to use the Async-Await pattern with common Azure Queue APIs.

trans-unit.source: The sample calls the async version of each of the given methods, this can be seen by the Async post-fix of each method.
trans-unit.target: The sample calls the async version of each of the given methods, this can be seen by the Async post-fix of each method.

trans-unit.source: When an async method is used the async-await pattern suspends local execution until the call completes.
trans-unit.target: When an async method is used the async-await pattern suspends local execution until the call completes.

trans-unit.source: This behavior allows the current thread to do other work which helps avoid performance bottlenecks and improves the overall responsiveness of your application.
trans-unit.target: This behavior allows the current thread to do other work which helps avoid performance bottlenecks and improves the overall responsiveness of your application.

trans-unit.source: For more details on using the Async-Await pattern in .NET see [Async and Await (C# and Visual Basic)] (https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh191443.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For more details on using the Async-Await pattern in .NET see [Async and Await (C# and Visual Basic)] (https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/hh191443.aspx)

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Delete method on the queue object.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Delete method on the queue object.
